. It's located along the border with Chungcheongbukdo in the city of Mungyeong.  It's just off Highway 3, and near the expressway 35/45.
The park consists of a valley surrounded by mountains.
It's up in the mountains, so a bit cooler and wetter.

Drive there from Seoul or Daegu on Expressway 35/45.  Get off at the Mungyeong Saejae interchange if you are approaching from the south, or at the Yeonpung interchange if from the north.  Then take Highway three to the entrance road.  It's three km down that side road to the park.

Or take a local bus from Jeomchon or from Mungyeong-eup to Kwan-mun.  This is the entrance to the park.  Check the schedule in advance - they don't come very often.  Intercity buses from Tong-Seoul, Daegu, and elsewhere stop at Mungyeong-eup, from where you can take the local bus or a taxi.  It's about six kilometers from the Mungyeong bus station to the park.  

Another option is to start at the north end of the trail.  This entails, by car, parking a fair bit below the road's end and walking (all uphill) from there.  Or, take a local bus from Suanbo or Yeonpung and walk the 3-4 km, all uphill, to the Saejae pass.

value: There's a movie set a ways up the trail.  It's a traditional Korean village - the southern part has grass rooves, the northern part  is where the yangban live (or would live if anyone lived there.)
A museum near the park entrance.
Hike along the old route between Kyeongsangdo and Seoul.  Climb the mountains on either side.  *Visit the temple, the movie set.

The tourist village is at the south entrance to the park.  The usual things are there: restaurants, minbaks, souvenir shops.
Restaurants are in the tourist village.  You can also find some establishments along the trail.  Identify them by the loud music they play, audible for much too far through the forest.
Soju.  Or, there's a nice mineral spring, Jagok Yaksu, partway up the trail.
